title: British companies issuing highest level of profit warnings for 11 years
text:
Companies listed in Britain have issued their highest number of profit warnings since the financial crisis, research today shows.

Professional services giant EY found that firms listed in London made 235 such cautions between January and September – the largest year-to-date figure since 2008.

These warnings are given when companies need to inform investors that profits will be less than previously expected.

Warnings: Companies listed in Britain have issued their highest number of profit warnings since the financial crisis

EY found that almost 18 per cent of listed UK companies have made profit warnings in the past 12 months.

Brexit was a particularly prominent concern for companies amid uncertainty about whether the UK would leave the European Union with a deal.

But EY found that 'escalating political and trade tensions in the global economy' had also hit profits.

Alan Hudson, EY's head of restructuring for the UK and Ireland, said: 'Although the economy is in better shape now than it was in 2008, there are clear parallels in terms of sheer unpredictability.

'Profit warnings aren't an absolute measure of performance, but they do track a company's ability to meet their forecasts, which is clearly more difficult in an uncertain environment.'

In the third quarter of 2019, between July and September, 77 profit warnings were made – up from 69 in the previous three months. Retail, software and computer services and media were the worst-performing sectors.
